headline: D.I.Y. Retirement Investors Have a Low-Cost Friend: Newsletters
keywords: ['Retirement', 'Personal Finances', 'Newsletters', 'Individual Retirement Accounts', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: For people who don’t want to pay high adviser fees and want to hold investments long term, the newsletters can be beneficial.
lead_paragraph: For Lori Walla, subscribing to an investment newsletter means more than the advice she gets to help her and her husband, Quincy, manage their Vanguard I.R.A.

headline: A Virus’s Journey Across China
abstract: Government officials thought they could control the disease and cover up its growing death toll. They were wrong.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: Where Did the $9 Million Cars Go?
keywords: ['Antique and Classic Cars', 'Auctions', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Collectors and Collections']
abstract: The classic auto market, humming just a few years ago, appears to be sliding into a downturn.
lead_paragraph: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — When classic cars hit the auction block these days, $3 million seems to be the new $10 million.

headline: Watch Bloomberg and Trump’s Very Different Super Bowl Ads
keywords: ['Political Advertising', 'Campaign Finance', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Super Bowl', 'Gun Control', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Michael R. Bloomberg’s campaign will air a 60-second ad promoting his record on gun control, while President Trump has lined up a commercial celebrating his time in office.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — Two billionaires will pitch their presidential candidacies amid the beer and car commercials of the Super Bowl on Sunday, with Michael R. Bloomberg spending a full minute addressing gun violence and President Trump using 30 seconds to highlight his first years in office.

headline: Novak Djokovic Outlasts Roger Federer to Stay Dominant in Australia
abstract: Djokovic prevailed in straight sets, extending his lead in head-to-head matches with Federer, to earn a place in the Australian Open final.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — If Thursday night’s straight-sets loss to Novak Djokovic turns out to be the last semifinal for Roger Federer at Rod Laver Arena, it was not a fitting sight.

headline: ‘Created Equal’ Review: A Justice of Few Words Finds His Voice
abstract: Clarence Thomas is usually silent on the Supreme Court, but he had plenty to say to some friendly filmmakers.
lead_paragraph: The most obvious selling point of “Created Equal: Clarence Thomas in His Own Words” also happens to be its most conspicuous deficiency.

headline: ‘The Assistant’ Review: Screaming on the Inside
abstract: Julia Garner is magnificent as a conflicted staffer to a serial sexual predator in this powerfully muted drama.
lead_paragraph: The specter of Harvey Weinstein looms over every frame of “The Assistant,” though we never see the face of the anonymous New York film-company executive whose toxic behavior drives the story. We hear him, though, laughing conspiratorially with a young female hopeful behind his tightly closed office door, or barking reprimands on the telephone to Jane (Julia Garner), his lowliest staffer.

headline: ‘Incitement’ Review: A Tense, Angry Reckoning With an Assassination
abstract: Yaron Zilberman’s film presents a discomfortingly close-range depiction of Yitzhak Rabin’s assassin in the period leading up to the killing.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli drama “Incitement” grabs a third rail and holds on tight. The movie, directed by Yaron Zilberman (“A Late Quartet”), presents a discomfortingly close-range depiction of what Yigal Amir saw and heard in the roughly two years before he assassinated Yitzhak Rabin, the prime minister, on Nov. 4, 1995.

headline: ‘The Rhythm Section’ Review: The Semi-Reluctant Assassin
abstract: Blake Lively plays a woman who loses her family and finds a new beat.
lead_paragraph: In the first minutes of “The Rhythm Section,” Blake Lively is seen as a purposeful but stressed-out assassin, a mild, loving member of an upper middle class British family, and a heroin-addicted prostitute. She inhabits all these personae with commitment. The actual order of events for her character, Stephanie, is family girl, addict, assassin. The director Reed Morano couches the domestic persona in soft diffused light and the hardened one in shallow-focus claustrophobia.

headline: Shakira? J. Lo? This Halftime Show Had Snakes and Indiana Jones
abstract: Chasing a “moment,” the show at the Super Bowl in 1995 is remembered as peak circus act. And it scared the “bejeebers” out of Patti LaBelle.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Dale Girard was wearing long underwear covered in what he said looked like “ectoplasmic slime from ‘Ghostbusters’” but was actually freezing cold fire gel. Costumed as “The Executioner,” he was in a holding area underneath a massive metal stage as it was being rolled onto the field at what was then known as Joe Robbie Stadium.

headline: On Politics: Where Are the Candidates Going?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Political Advertising']
abstract: Strategic Iowa trips, a Sanders cash haul, Facebook ads: This is your morning tipsheet.
lead_paragraph: With the caucuses looming, any space in Iowa can become a political venue. Take, for example, this museum that sells historical furniture, RVP-1875, which hosted a Buttigieg event on Wednesday in Jefferson, Iowa.

headline: Elon Musk Hits Back at Critics
abstract: Tesla reported a $105 million quarterly profit yesterday, convincing backers that the company has solved its problems — while doubters aren’t convinced.
lead_paragraph: Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.

headline: Longest Smuggling Tunnel Is Found at U.S.-Mexico Border
abstract: The shaft ran for four-fifths of a mile between Tijuana and San Diego and was equipped with rails, ventilation, a drainage system and even an elevator, officials said.
lead_paragraph: Ventilation tubes and electricity cables run along the rough-hewed walls. Rudimentary rails stretch along the ground. The dank, waterlogged conditions belie the desert conditions at the surface, some 70 feet above.

headline: Press Send for Brexit: E.U. Seals U.K. Withdrawal by Email
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: The European Union’s 27 remaining member nations signed off on Britain’s departure in a typically low-key and bureaucratic style.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It’s done. At last. The European Union gave its final, formal approval to Brexit on Thursday, clearing the way for Britain to reverse 47 years of integration with the Continent and leave the bloc on Friday night.

headline: Sorry, but Those Kids Are Terrible
abstract: A reader wonders whether her attitude toward her nieces and nephews really needs to be adjusted.
lead_paragraph: My husband has four nieces and nephews between the ages of 2 and 10. They are unruly, unintelligent and uninteresting compared to other children we know. We don’t think their parents do a good job with them, and all the grandparents pitching in from the sidelines only leads to confusion and worse behavior. We keep to ourselves at family events and count the minutes until we can leave. Recently, one of the grandparents called to scold us for our bad attitude toward the children and suggested we not attend future events if we can’t accept them as they are. But isn’t it unfair to ask us to change without asking the same of the children or their parents?

headline: Japan Seeks Arrests of 3 Americans Accused of Helping Ghosn Escape
abstract: Authorities issued warrants for men suspected of helping smuggle the former executive out of the country to avoid criminal charges.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japanese prosecutors on Thursday issued arrest warrants for three Americans suspected of helping the former Nissan chairman Carlos Ghosn flee the country, where he was awaiting trial on charges of financial wrongdoing.

headline: The Work Diary of Jessica Walsh, Designing (and Wining) Woman
abstract: The graphic designer and founder of a creative agency powers through insomnia, migraines and helping mom with Instagram.
lead_paragraph: Jessica Walsh is in the 0.1 percent. That’s how few founders of ad agencies with national or international accounts are female, according to Ad Age.

headline: Altria Takes a $4.1 Billion Hit on Juul Stake
abstract: After an earlier write-down of $4.5 billion, the tobacco giant’s stake in the vaping start-up is now worth one-third of what it paid in 2018.
lead_paragraph: Altria reported a $4.1 billion write-down on its Juul Labs investment on Thursday, another sizable charge as the vaping crisis continues to roil the e-cigarette industry.

headline: ‘Every Day Matters’: Guardian Stops Accepting Fossil Fuel Ads
keywords: ['Newspapers', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Natural Gas', 'Coal']
abstract: It said the decision was based on the efforts by the industry to prevent meaningful climate action by governments.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Guardian newspaper said it would stop accepting advertisements from oil and gas companies, making it the latest institution to limit financial ties to fossil fuel businesses.

headline: Berkeley Law School Drops Boalt Name Over Racist Legacy
abstract: Thursday: It’s a rare move within the University of California. Also: The latest on a high-profile housing bill.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
abstract: A new wine bar that doesn’t skimp on the food — and more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we’re sharing things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. You can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

headline: Trump Administration Moves to Relax Rules Against Killing Birds
keywords: ['Birds', 'Animal Migration', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Natural Gas', 'Wind Power', 'Environment', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A proposed regulation would codify a legal opinion in 2017 that declared the accidental killing of birds during the course of business as no longer subject to punishment.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration on Thursday moved to drop the threat of punishment to oil and gas companies, construction crews and other organizations that kill birds “incidentally,” arguing that businesses that accidentally kill birds ought to be able to operate without fear of prosecution.

headline: Polarization Is Rational
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Liberalism (US Politics)']
abstract: It’s also a problem.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.

headline: Which Cities Are Renters Fleeing, and Where Are They Going?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Moving and Moving Industry']
abstract: A new study finds that people on the move are attracted to Denver — especially if they live in Washington, D.C. Here’s a look at some other popular migration patterns.
lead_paragraph: Americans have long migrated from city to city in search of a better life, changing the face of regional real estate markets as they go. Now, internet searches for out-of-town rentals can predict these changes before they occur.

headline: 7 Questions With Jazz Jennings of TLC’s ‘I Am Jazz’
abstract: Her transition has been documented in the public eye for more than a decade. The newest season of her reality show began this week.
lead_paragraph: Jazz Jennings has been in the spotlight since 2007, when she was 6 and appeared on the ABC News program “20/20.” Wearing a dress, she opened up to Barbara Walters about being a transgender child, at a time when mainstream audiences didn’t often hear from those voices.

headline: Cruise Passengers Are Held at Italian Port in False Alarm Over Coronavirus
abstract: For an entire day, passengers on the cruise ship were blocked from disembarking after a woman onboard became sick. She did not have the disease, but Italy did identify its first two cases in Rome.
lead_paragraph: CIVITAVECCHIA, Italy — Thousands of passengers stuck on a towering cruise ship. Doctors racing to the scene. Confusion and fear spreading.

headline: She Painted With the Hairy Who. Now She’s Going Big, at 79.
abstract: Gladys Nilsson, a bold watercolorist rooted in Chicago’s surrealist ’60s art group, on finally finding solo success.
lead_paragraph: In 1966, Gladys Nilsson and five other young artists organized an exhibition of their work in Chicago’s Hyde Park Art Center, and overnight became the talk of the town. The group called themselves the Hairy Who.

headline: How the Co-Founder of the Malala Fund Pivoted to Cookware
abstract: Shiza Shahid has brought her thoughtfulness and entrepreneurial spirit to a line of items for the modern, multiethnic American kitchen.
lead_paragraph: In “One Good Meal,” we ask cooking-inclined creative people to share the story behind a favorite dish they actually make and eat at home on a regular basis — and not just when they’re trying to impress.

headline: The Perfect ’72 Dolphins and Football’s Ultimate Toll
abstract: The N.F.L. is celebrating its only team to go through an entire season without losing. That glory came at a cost as several of the team’s prominent players were found to have C.T.E.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS, Ga. — In a ranch house not far from the stadium where Bill Stanfill played college football, there is a picture of the hulking defensive lineman from the final seconds of the Super Bowl played at the end of the 1972 season. In the black-and-white photo, Stanfill and a teammate, Vern Den Herder, are tackling Washington Redskins quarterback Billy Kilmer.

headline: ‘Star Trek: Picard’ Recap: Out in the Cold
abstract: Picard is running out of time, as he discovers in the season’s second episode. But he’s also just getting started.
lead_paragraph: In the second episode of “Star Trek: Picard,” we learn about a super secret group of Romulans, called Zhat Vash. I admit I’m not sure if I’m spelling that correctly, which is partially a good sign: It means there’s something new being introduced in the familiar “Trek” universe (or old, depending on how you look at it).

headline: As Coronavirus Spreads, So Does Anti-Chinese Sentiment
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Epidemics', 'Travel Warnings', 'SARS (Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome)', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Fears of the outbreak have fueled xenophobia as a wave of panic spreads, sometimes outstripping practical concerns.
lead_paragraph: In Japan, the hashtag #ChineseDon’tComeToJapan has been trending on Twitter. In Singapore, tens of thousands of residents have signed a petition calling for the government to ban Chinese nationals from entering the country.

headline: Trump Administration Unveils a Major Shift in Medicaid
keywords: ['Medicaid', 'States (US)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Poverty', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'your-feed-healthcare']
abstract: States will be able to cap a portion of spending for the safety-net program, a change likely to diminish the number of people receiving health benefits through it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration said on Thursday that it would allow states to cap Medicaid spending for many poor adults, a major shift long sought by conservatives that gives states the option of reducing health benefits for millions who gained coverage through the program under the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Jennifer Lopez at the Super Bowl? It’s the Role She Was Born to Play
keywords: ['Pop and Rock Music', 'Movies', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'Super Bowl', 'Football', 'Academy Awards (Oscars)']
abstract: The halftime show demands a pop unicorn. Twenty-one years into a music career that doesn’t always get enough credit, J. Lo is ready to take center stage.
lead_paragraph: Some time in 1998, riding high on critical acclaim for her performance alongside George Clooney in Steven Soderbergh’s sultry crime thriller “Out of Sight,” the rising actress Jennifer Lopez approached her manager with an unconventional idea: She wanted to make an album.

headline: Pompeo Calls China’s Ruling Party ‘Central Threat of Our Times’
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Politics and Government', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States International Relations', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', '5G (Wireless Communications)']
abstract: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo made the stark statement at a meeting with his British counterpart, where he also talked up the prospect of a U.S. trade deal with Britain.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Secretary of State Mike Pompeo declared the Chinese Communist Party “the central threat of our times” on Thursday, even as he sought to talk up the prospects of a United States trade deal with Britain, which rebuffed American pressure to ban a Chinese company from future telecommunications infrastructure.

keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', "Alzheimer's Disease", 'SARS (Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome)', 'Prostate Gland', 'Heart', 'Elderly', 'Longevity', 'Hygiene and Cleanliness', 'Muscles', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Medicine and Health', 'Optimism', 'Exercise']

headline: Wilbur Ross Says Coronavirus Could Bring Jobs Back to the U.S.
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Relocation of Business', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: The commerce secretary said the virus, while “very unfortunate,” could prompt companies to reconsider operating inside China.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross predicted Thursday morning that a deadly virus originating in China would cause companies to reconsider their global supply chains and ultimately “help to accelerate” the return of jobs to the United States.

headline: 20 Reds Under $20: Where the Values Live, for Now
abstract: The wine world is anxious as tariffs have been threatened against all wines from the European Union. These prices may not last for long.
lead_paragraph: The wine world looks a little different now than it did in September, when the last 20 Under $20 column was published, and further radical changes may be on the way.

headline: More Violence. Fewer Prisoners. Inside Mexico’s Criminal Justice Reform.
keywords: ['Criminal Justice', 'Politics and Government', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Law and Legislation', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Leaked drafts of reforms intended to strengthen the government’s hand in the fight against crime have outraged judicial and human rights workers.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The raid delivered a resounding blow to Mexico City’s most fearsome criminal group: 31 suspected gang members were arrested, two drug labs were uncovered and a criminal bounty was seized, including two and a half tons of marijuana, 44 pounds of cocaine and an arsenal of weapons.

headline: International Center of Photography Refocuses in a New Home
abstract: When images are everywhere, what is the role of a photography museum?
lead_paragraph: It’s not just your cellphone that’s a camera now. Your doorbell can take photographs, and so might your car, your refrigerator and your toothbrush. Camera-sporting athletes now do the work of sports photojournalists, and all New York City beat cops wear a body camera. War photography has gone from a specialist’s art to a citizen’s daily action, and the stupid selfie you uploaded yesterday has already been scraped into a database and could be sold to law enforcement agencies or a private detective. This is the paradox: the average photograph has never been more banal or irrelevant, yet photography as a medium has never mattered more.

headline: Royal Ballet Suspends Choreographer Over Sexual Misconduct Claims
abstract: Liam Scarlett is accused of inappropriate conduct with students at the company’s school.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Royal Ballet has suspended Liam Scarlett, its artist-in-residence, after accusations of sexual misconduct involving students at the Royal Ballet School.

headline: German Nurse Accused of Poisoning Five Infants With Morphine
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Hospitals', 'Children and Childhood', 'Morphine', 'Nursing and Nurses']
abstract: The babies, who ranged in age from a day to a month old, started experiencing respiratory difficulties about the same time, leading a hospital to investigate.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The staff at a hospital in southwestern Germany was puzzled when five infants sharing the same room all developed breathing trouble at the same time in December. Extra nurses were called in to monitor and gently nudge the babies when their breathing stopped.

headline: French Cardinal Acquitted of Abuse Cover-Up on Appeal
abstract: Cardinal Philippe Barbarin, the archbishop of Lyon, had been found guilty last year of failing to report a priest in his diocese who had admitted to sexually abusing dozens of Boy Scouts.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A French appeals court on Thursday overturned a ruling against a cardinal who had been found guilty of covering up decades-old sexual abuse by a priest in his diocese, the latest twist in the most high-profile legal case against a clergyman in France.

headline: ‘Gretel & Hansel’ Review: Brother’s Keeper
abstract: In this eerie yet underdeveloped take on the well-known fairy tale, two siblings find food and sorcery deep in the woods.
lead_paragraph: The director Osgood Perkins specializes in not-quite-horror movies: eerie, patient, female-centric tales that hint at far more than they reveal. In “I Am the Pretty Thing That Lives in the House” (2016), he teased a standard haunting into a conversation between life and death. And with the more bloody “Blackcoat’s Daughter” (released in the U.S. in 2017), he used shifting timelines and an isolated girls’ boarding school to examine grief and abandonment.

headline: Lincoln Center’s Next Season: ‘Elektra,’ Cleveland, Rouse
abstract: The 2020-21 Great Performers series includes visiting orchestras, chamber ensembles and recitals.
lead_paragraph: Esa-Pekka Salonen will lead a concert version of Strauss’s “Elektra.” Franz Welser-Möst will conduct the Cleveland Orchestra in Mozart and Morton Feldman. Louis Langrée and the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra will give the first New York performance of Christopher Rouse’s Symphony No. 6, which they premiered last year, shortly after its composer’s death.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Racial Diversity by Neighborhood
abstract: How has racial diversity in American neighborhoods changed since 1980?
lead_paragraph: These graphs, which show the extent to which U.S. neighborhoods are racially integrated (white and nonwhite) for 1980, 2000 and 2017, appeared elsewhere on NYTimes.com.

headline: What Made Virginia Change Its Mind on Guns?
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'State Legislatures', 'Politics and Government', 'Population', 'Richmond, Va, Gun Rally (January, 2020)']
abstract: Attitudes about guns are shifting in the state amid demographic changes. In one State Senate district that flipped to Democratic control in November, guns were a key topic.
lead_paragraph: MIDLOTHIAN, Va. — Lisette Johnson had been a lifelong Republican. She became an activist on gun safety after she was shot by her estranged husband more than a decade ago, and she asked her Republican state senator for his backing on gun control bills.

headline: Is South Bend a Prosperous College Town or a Struggling Rust Belt City?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Urban Areas', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Mayors', 'Politics and Government', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Two very different perceptions have taken hold of the place Pete Buttigieg has made a centerpiece of his campaign.
lead_paragraph: SOUTH BEND, Ind. — This city, according to Americans with only a vague notion of it, is a down-home, run-down, industrial, beautiful, Catholic kind of place. It is progressive and conservative, country and urban, dangerous and quaint. A college town, really, but with high poverty. And corn.

headline: 10 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Ask any reading group: People disagree about books all the time. But it’s rare for a novel to be quite as polarizing, or as controversial in the wider culture, as Jeanine Cummins’s new book, “American Dirt,” has turned out to be.

headline: National Asian American Theater Partners With Regional Companies
abstract: The initiative, with New York Theater Workshop, Soho Rep and others, aims to foster inclusion of Asian-American theater artists, technicians and administrators.
lead_paragraph: The National Asian American Theater Company is starting a partnership with regional theaters across the country, aiming to foster inclusion of more Asian-American theater artists, technicians, administrators and community members through productions, outreach and other programming.

headline: House Votes to Repeal 2002 Military Authorization in Bid to Rein in Trump on Iran
keywords: ['War Powers Act (1973)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'War and Emergency Powers (US)', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The law has been used to justify all manner of military strikes since Congress approved it to authorize President George W. Bush to take military action in Iraq.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House on Thursday moved to block President Trump from taking military action against Iran without the approval of Congress, voting to repeal a 2002 war authorization and to bar him from using federal funds to mount an unauthorized strike against Tehran.

headline: ‘I’m a Democrat’: Biden Accuses Sanders of Not Being a Party Member
abstract: Mr. Biden’s attack on his rival in Iowa came hours after another leading candidate, Pete Buttigieg, criticized both men, in a day of sparring that underscored the pressure they all face to excel in Monday’s caucuses.
lead_paragraph: PELLA, Iowa — In one of his most direct confrontations yet with his top rival in the Iowa caucuses, former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Thursday called out Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont for not being a Democrat even as Mr. Sanders makes a competitive run for that party’s presidential nomination, and Mr. Biden also jabbed Mr. Sanders’s record on gun control in among his most detailed remarks on the matter to date.

headline: E. Jean Carroll, Who Accused Trump of Rape, Seeks His DNA in Lawsuit
abstract: Ms. Carroll says that President Trump assaulted her in the 1990s, and that she has the dress she was wearing during the incident.
lead_paragraph: The writer E. Jean Carroll, who has accused Donald J. Trump of raping her in the 1990s and is suing him for defamation, asked on Thursday that he provide a DNA sample to determine whether his genetic material is on a dress she says she had on at the time of the incident.

headline: After the Oscar Glare, These Filmmakers Went Their Own Way
abstract: Benh Zeitlin (“Beasts of the Southern Wild”) and Tom McCarthy (“Spotlight”) each found that the awards machine distracted from the real work.
lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah — When the writer-director Benh Zeitlin was unexpectedly thrust into the middle of the Oscar melee in 2012 with his debut feature, “Beasts of the Southern Wild,” it was a surreal, discomforting experience filled with stiff tuxedos and awkward small talk — light years away from his ragtag existence in New Orleans, where he makes lyrical, atmospheric movies with his friends.

headline: How Iowa Could Decide Joe Biden’s Fund-Raising Future
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Political Advertising', 'Political Action Committees', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: As Mr. Biden barnstorms the state in the final days before the caucuses, he is chasing more than voters and delegates. The biggest stakes for him might just be cash.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s campaign has quietly rolled back hundreds of thousands of dollars of television ad reservations in New Hampshire and South Carolina in recent weeks and redirected the funds to buy more ads in Iowa instead.

headline: A Gorgeous Center for Photography, Far From Picture Perfect
abstract: Fotografiska, the New York outpost of the quirky Swedish institution, is an “architectural gem,” but the exhibited photographs don’t live up to the décor.
lead_paragraph: In an image-saturated world, Fotografiska — a Stockholm institution that has recently established an outpost in New York — aims to lure people off their phones to venture out to see photographs displayed on walls. The strategy is brilliant: provide in the real world what people seek in virtual reality. Give them a community that revolves around photographs, and which in turn will supply them with pictures they can funnel back into their Instagram feeds.

headline: Affirmative Action: The Uniquely American Experiment
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Discrimination', 'AFFIRMATIVE ACTION', 'Minorities', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: In “The Affirmative Action Puzzle,” Melvin I. Urofsky looks at over a century of efforts to combat racial injustice in America.
lead_paragraph: THE AFFIRMATIVE ACTION PUZZLEA Living History From Reconstruction to TodayBy Melvin I. Urofsky

headline: Free Shakespeare in the Park: ‘Richard II’ and ‘As You Like It’
abstract: The Public Theater’s summer lineup includes a serious tale of political rebellion and a musical take on a comedy.
lead_paragraph: The Public Theater announced on Thursday that it will bring a new production of “Richard II” and a version of its 2017 musical adaptation of “As You Like It” to the Delacorte Theater in Central Park this summer for its free Shakespeare in the Park series.

headline: Here’s What We Know About Kobe Bryant’s Helicopter Route
abstract: A deeper look at the route of Kobe Bryant’s helicopter before it crashed to understand how such an accident could occur.
lead_paragraph: A deeper look at the route of Kobe Bryant’s helicopter before it crashed to understand how such an accident could occur.

headline: In Los Angeles, Kobe and Wealthy Elites Use Helicopters as Taxis
keywords: ['Helicopters', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']
abstract: In a video, we retraced Kobe Bryant’s route before the crash that killed him and eight others to try to understand what might have happened.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — For celebrities and the rich of Los Angeles, the helicopters that constantly whir above the city are a glitzy status symbol. In some neighborhoods, they are a menacing symbol of police surveillance. For almost everyone, including the conductor who once walked offstage during Mahler’s Symphony No. 8 when a helicopter buzzed above the Hollywood Bowl, they can be a hated nuisance.

headline: Billionaire Yusaku Maezawa Calls Off TV Search for Moon Trip ‘Life Partner’
keywords: ['Private Spaceflight', 'Rocket Science and Propulsion', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Moon']
abstract: Yusaku Maezawa had posted an advertisement seeking a woman to go with him on a SpaceX flight around the moon. He said he canceled the search for “personal reasons” and apologized.
lead_paragraph: Yusaku Maezawa sought love in the way only a lonely, 44-year-old fashion billionaire could: asking the women of the internet to apply for a chance to accompany him on a spaceflight around the moon — if they had “bright and positive” personalities and were over 20.

headline: Bernie Sanders Is Still Sad About the Dodgers
abstract: And he knows how to nurse a grudge.
lead_paragraph: BURLINGTON, Iowa — The role was not an artistic stretch.

headline: ‘Taylor Swift: Miss Americana’ Review: A Star, Surprisingly Alone
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Pop and Rock Music']
abstract: In the Netflix documentary, we see a star that is self-critical, grown up and ready, perhaps, to deliver a message beyond the music.
lead_paragraph: “Miss Americana” is 85 minutes of translucence with Taylor Swift. There’s more in it — and more to it — than you usually get with these pop superstar portraits. I, at least, don’t recall loneliness being such a predominant condition for Swift’s peers as it is, here, for her. Not long after the movie doles out a deluxe rise-to-the-top montage, we hear Swift ask no one in particular, “Shouldn’t I have someone to call right now?” This from a woman who’s famous — notorious, actually — for her squad of besties. Otherwise, it’s lonely up there. Even the man she says she’s seeing is a figment in this movie, cropped from images, a hand-holding blur, a ghost.

headline: Coronavirus Anger Boils Over in China and Doctors Plead for Supplies
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Shortages', 'Politics and Government', 'Evacuations and Evacuees', 'Protective Clothing and Gear']
abstract: A man was detained after beating up a doctor in Wuhan, and medical staff members are wearing raincoats to protect against infection.
lead_paragraph: WUHAN, China — One week into a lockdown, anger and anxiety deepened in China on Thursday as the central province at the center of the coronavirus outbreak endured shortages of hospital beds, medical supplies and doctors.

headline: A New Home for the City Bakery’s Hot Chocolate
abstract: The Wonderbon Chocolate Company, from the founder of the shuttered bakery, is opening a West Village pop-up serving the hot drink.
lead_paragraph: The City Bakery closed last year, and fans of its hot chocolate worried that that would be the end. But the bakery’s founder, Maury Rubin, is opening the Wonderbon Chocolate Company on Saturday, with a new partner, Alex Atzberger, a chocolate aficionado. The pop-up is a celebration of all things chocolate, starting with steaming cups of the hot kind. The counter-service shop occupies the space that some might recall as home to the original Murray’s Cheese, now across the street.

headline: W.H.O. Declares Global Emergency as Wuhan Coronavirus Spreads
abstract: The announcement came as nearly 10,000 cases have been reported worldwide.
lead_paragraph: The World Health Organization declared a global health emergency on Thursday as the coronavirus outbreak spread well beyond China, where it emerged last month.

headline: Coronavirus and the Panic Epidemic
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Politics and Government', 'Epidemics', 'Lunar New Year', 'SARS (Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome)']
abstract: The Chinese government is going all-out because it knows the people don’t entirely trust it.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The absurdity of the situation hit me on Wednesday when I was coming home from a local bar at 8 p.m. I had ridden my bike a few hours earlier to a park for a walk and then to meet a friend — my first human contact in five days, excluding the cashier at the grocery store.

headline: California, Mired in a Housing Crisis, Rejects an Effort to Ease It
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Affordable Housing', 'Homeless Persons', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Urban Areas', 'Law and Legislation', 'Zoning', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Politics and Government', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: A lawmaker’s push for denser development near transit, overriding local zoning, was thwarted by a diverse group of legislative foes.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For years, a determined state senator has pushed a singular vision: a bill challenging California’s devotion to both single-family housing and motor vehicles by stripping away limits on housing density near public transit.

headline: Harlan Coben Exposes the Secrets of ‘The Stranger’
abstract: The author of dozens of best-selling thrillers talked about his latest Netflix adaptation and why the most gripping stories are rooted in everyday life.
lead_paragraph: There are many writers of best-selling thrillers out there, but few are as savvy about television as Harlan Coben.

headline: What Students Are Saying About What Kobe Bryant’s Death Means to Them
abstract: More than 350 teenagers paid tribute to the retired Los Angeles Lakers star and his daughter who were killed in a helicopter crash Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Please note: This post is part of The Learning Network’s ongoing Current Events Conversation feature. We invite students to react to the news via our daily writing prompts and, each week, we publish a selection of their comments.

headline: Coronavirus, India Citizenship Protests, Brexit: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Starving for Justice in ICE Detention
abstract: For immigrants languishing behind bars, a hunger strike is often the sole remaining means of protest against a dehumanizing and unjust system.
lead_paragraph: On Jan. 29, Immigration and Customs Enforcement deported to India an asylum-seeker who had spent nearly eight months in ICE detention. He was one of five asylum-seekers of South Asian origin who went on a hunger strike in October at the LaSalle Detention Center, an ICE processing facility in Jena, La, operated by the for-profit prison company GEO Group. All five had exercised their legal right to claim asylum, after escaping religious or political persecution.

headline: Desert Empires: Wonders to Behold
abstract: Two hundred rare objects at the Metropolitan Museum trace the remarkable history and cultural heritage of kingdoms on the rim of the Sahara.
lead_paragraph: Bucket lists form early. When I was, maybe, 10, flipping through books in my grandfather’s house I came across a photograph of the Great Mosque at Djenné in Mali, West Africa, and thought, this is the strangest, most wonderful, most outer-space building I’ve ever seen. Beige-color and turreted, it was as soft-edged as a sand castle, but huge, dwarfing people in street. I wanted to go there.

headline: ‘American Dirt’ Has Us Talking. That’s a Good Thing.
abstract: The publishing industry changed its opinion of Mexican immigrant stories only after someone outside our community wrote one.
lead_paragraph: Last fall, I was sent an advance copy of Jeanine Cummins’s new novel, “American Dirt,” and a request for an endorsement. As a Mexican-American woman and an immigrant, it was clear to me that I was not the intended audience for this story. And yet, I found it compelling. I noticed its shortcomings, the things she got wrong about our culture and experience, but saw past them. I felt that a book like this could complement the Latino immigrant literature that has and will continue to be written by Latino writers, myself included.

headline: Film Club: ‘Never Too Old for a Tiara’
abstract: Are you ever too old to do something?
lead_paragraph: “Never Too Old for a Tiara” is a six-minute film that touches on themes of aging, beauty and breaking stereotypes about what older adults can or can’t do. It profiles competitors in the Ms. Senior America contest, who unlike Miss America beauty pageant contestants are not women on the cusp of adulthood, but instead are women who have experienced life in all of its joys and sorrows. They’re still kicking — and kicking high.

headline: Before Patrick Mahomes Was a Headliner, the Chiefs Could See He’d Be a Star
abstract: A training camp for the ages: When the Kansas City quarterback was a rookie, tapes of his play went viral within the coaching staff. Mahomes rode the bench that season. Then came decision time.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — In 2017, the Kansas City Chiefs traded three draft picks to move up 17 spots and take Patrick Mahomes with the 10th pick of the N.F.L. draft, but as a rookie, he played in only one game, a throwaway appearance on the season’s final weekend. Mahomes’s workload did not portend the risky, bold move to come.

headline: Trump and Lincoln: How Politics Influences Decisions
abstract: A reader rebuts an Op-Ed writer’s claim that both presidents’ actions were motivated by personal interests. Also: Teenagers, phones and parents; sugar in the diet.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Fossilized Tooth Captures a Pterosaur’s Failed Squid Meal
abstract: The unlikely fossil sheds new light on the flying reptile’s dining habits.
lead_paragraph: About 150 million years ago, a pterosaur experienced an embarrassing mealtime mishap. Attempting to catch and eat a seafood snack, the flying reptile came away one tooth short.

headline: Complex Rhythms but No Music
abstract: Watch a portion of Melinda Ring’s “Strange Engagements,” created from improvisations.
lead_paragraph: #SpeakingInDance is a weekly visual exploration of dance on Instagram. Watch the video from our most recent post below, and follow us at @nytimes.

headline: They Heard Kobe Bryant’s Helicopter Go Down. Then They Prayed.
abstract: At a church down the hill from a disaster, Sunday played out in small moments: a low-flying helicopter, a note slipped to the pastor, a driver looking for nine clients who never arrived.
lead_paragraph: CALABASAS, Calif. — It began as just another Sunday at a little church along Las Virgenes Road, on a quiet edge of suburban Los Angeles. The Church in the Canyon is an unremarkable box of a building, with a flat roof over glass front doors.

headline: Trump on Trial, and a Test for America
abstract: Readers urge senators to vote to convict or to merely vote “present” as a protest, and wonder about Alan Dershowitz, “Was he serious?”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Super Bowl Is Problematic. Why Can’t We Look Away?
abstract: The halftime show, the ads, the parties: The Super Bowl is more than a game, and 100 million of us tune in despite the sport’s uglier controversies. Our culture journalists discussed the reasons and implications.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN CONSIDINE Friends: I know what I’m doing Sunday. I know what you’re doing Sunday. As full-time culture journalists, to ignore the Super Bowl would be a gross dereliction of duty. That’s because the Super Bowl isn’t just a game. It’s the halftime show; it’s the ads; it’s the chips and guac. It is sport but also music, dance, costumes, TV production and stage design — a pop culture event greater than the sum of its parts.

headline: The Fed Wants to Loosen Rules Around Big Banks and Venture Capital
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Venture Capital', 'Private Equity']
abstract: Proposed tweaks to the Volcker Rule, which curbs bank risk-taking, would allow firms to invest heavily in funds backing start-ups.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Banks could invest heavily in or even sponsor venture capital funds under a proposed change to a post-crisis rule that was intended to limit their risk-taking.

headline: Ginni Rometty to Step Down as C.E.O. of IBM
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Computers and the Internet']

lead_paragraph: Ginni Rometty, the longtime face of IBM and one of the country’s most prominent female business leaders, is stepping down as chief executive, the company said on Thursday.

headline: Abduction of Ethiopian Students Fuels Anger at the Government
keywords: ['Kidnapping and Hostages', 'Women and Girls', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Politics and Government', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: The failure of Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed’s government to rescue a group of students who were believed to have been kidnapped last month and forced into the jungle has bred protests and anguish.
lead_paragraph: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia — Ethiopians are taking to the streets and to social media to protest their government’s failure to find at least a dozen university students and five other people who were believed to have been kidnapped from a bus by masked men in December in the latest in a chain of ethnically driven conflicts.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: Puzzles, paintings, ghost brides: plenty to watch this weekend, and our critic has recommendations.
lead_paragraph: No matter how much free time you have this weekend, we have TV recommendations for you. Come back every week for new suggestions on what to watch.

headline: Leila Janah, Entrepreneur Who Hired the Poor, Dies at 37
abstract: A child of Indian immigrants, she created digital jobs that pay a living wage to thousands in Africa and India, believing that the intellect of the poor was “the biggest untapped resource” in the world.
lead_paragraph: Leila Janah, a social entrepreneur who employed thousands of desperately poor people in Africa and India in the fervent belief that jobs, not handouts, offered the best escape from poverty, died on Jan. 24 in Manhattan. She was 37.

headline: Wes Wilson, Psychedelic Poster Pioneer, Dies at 82
abstract: His work announced concerts by the Grateful Dead, Jefferson Airplane and more — to those who could read them.
lead_paragraph: Wes Wilson, who helped create the trippy look associated with the second half of the 1960s through the vivid, swirling posters he made for rock shows by the Grateful Dead, Jefferson Airplane and others, died on Jan. 24 at his home in Leanne, Mo. He was 82.

headline: Fred Silverman, 82, Is Dead; a TV Power When Three Networks Ruled
abstract: A top executive at CBS, ABC and then NBC, he shepherded series like “All in the Family,” “Laverne & Shirley” and “Hill Street Blues.”

He was 82.

But it is far from clear how much of this story the public will be permitted to read, and when.

Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. once preached. Over the decades, the 6,000-member congregation just east of downtown Atlanta has become a favored stop for national politicians seeking to make their case to the African-American community and pay homage to the slain civil rights icon.

lead_paragraph: New York City’s antiquated method of calculating property taxes has long allowed owners of multimillion-dollar brownstones in Brooklyn and high-rise co-ops by Central Park to pay less in taxes than working-class homeowners in the South Bronx, relative to the value of their properties.

headline: Did I Just Get Yanged?
keywords: ['Primaries and Caucuses', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Income Inequality', 'Asian-Americans', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Andrew Yang is showing what healthy populism looks like.
lead_paragraph: It was New Year’s Eve, and I had decided to spend it with Andrew Yang. A self-described “Asian man who’s good at math,” Mr. Yang had raised an impressive $16.5 million in the fourth quarter of 2019 for his presidential campaign. Despite being newly flush, the campaign didn’t hold its shindig in a Napa Valley wine cave or at Gramercy Tavern, but in a fluorescent-lit room above a bar in Nashua, N.H.

headline: Helicopter in Kobe Bryant Crash Wasn’t Legal to Fly in Poor Visibility
abstract: The pilot who flew Mr. Bryant and seven others through deteriorating weather was qualified to fly with the use of his instruments. But the company he worked for didn’t have the needed certification.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — When the helicopter carrying the basketball legend Kobe Bryant crashed into a fogbound mountainside on Sunday, killing all nine people onboard, the pilot who was struggling to avoid the clouds did not have the legal authority to navigate with his instruments because the aircraft owner did not have the necessary federal certification, according to three sources familiar with the charter helicopter company’s operations.

headline: ‘Medea’ Review: Rose Byrne and Bobby Cannavale, Torched by Love
abstract: Simon Stone’s contemporary spin on the classic tale of marital vengeance feels more clinical than tragic.
lead_paragraph: Though their deaths made their mother eternally infamous, little is known about the children Medea murdered. So give some credit to the writer and director Simon Stone’s otherwise unilluminating “Medea” for making us think — with personal concern as well as generic terror — about what it must have felt like to be the progeny of its rage-filled title character.

abstract: For the last three years, Britons have debated Brexit. Now that it is here, there is a sense of relief even though the country still must decide what sort of Brexit it wants.

Yet for all the gravity of the moment, there is a palpable sense of anticlimax.

headline: What’s on TV Friday: ‘Bojack Horseman’ and ‘Spider-Man: Far From Home’
abstract: The final episodes of “Bojack Horseman” hit Netflix. And the most recent “Spider-Man” movie airs on Starz.
lead_paragraph: BOJACK HORSEMAN Stream on Netflix. After six seasons swilling whiskey and deadpanning, the sweater-wearing title character of this animated Hollywood satire is putting down the reins. The series has followed Bojack, an anthropomorphic horse voiced by Will Arnett, as he navigates a fictional version of Hollywood, where he lives as a has-been 1990s sitcom star. Toward the end of the most recent batch of episodes, he accepted a job at Wesleyan University. How he adjusts to collegiate life will be one of the questions that the final installments — which hit Netflix on Friday — will answer.

headline: An Outbreak of Racist Sentiment as Coronavirus Reaches Australia
abstract: A newspaper front page called it a “Chinese virus.” Fake posts have warned people to avoid Chinese products. As the outbreak spreads, some worry about xenophobia.
lead_paragraph: Recently, when Andy Miao takes the train to work in Sydney, he has noticed other people’s disapproving looks if he does not wear a face mask. Although he does not have the coronavirus, Mr. Miao, who is of Chinese heritage and grew up in Australia, knows it’s because of one reason: his ethnicity.

headline: Pharmacists Make Mistakes. You Can Protect Yourself.
abstract: Medication errors come in many forms. Check the label. Read the instructions. Ask your pharmacist questions.
lead_paragraph: Lynne Calloway had been taking a newly refilled arthritis prescription for a few days when she mentioned she wasn’t feeling well.

headline: Generations of Exiles Collide in Post-Katrina New Orleans
abstract: In Michael Zapata’s debut novel, “The Lost Book of Adana Moreau,” an unfinished sci-fi manuscript bridges multiple universes, cosmic and human.
lead_paragraph: Suppose that we live in a universe without “ifs.” What appears to be chance, or choice, is actually a peek into the rules of a completely separate universe that we can never access. Here, all our hopes for what might have been or what could be are accounted for; every outcome is settled, and we must play it as it lays.

headline: Is It Offensive for Sports Teams and Their Fans to Use Native American Names, Imagery and Gestures?
abstract: The Kansas City Chiefs will face the San Francisco 49ers for Super Bowl LIV. Chiefs fans regularly use a “tomahawk chop” to urge on their beloved team: Is it offensive?
lead_paragraph: Native American names and symbols have long been used by all types of American sports teams at the professional, college and high school levels, such as the Cleveland Indians, Atlanta Braves and Washington Redskins. But facing pressure and protest, many teams are now changing their nicknames and mascots.

headline: My Father the Heartbreaker
keywords: ['Mental Health and Disorders', 'Depression (Mental)', 'Marriages', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: When my father was alive and raging and breaking our hearts, I didn’t understand that he had a broken heart, too.
lead_paragraph: On the day after Christmas in 1996, my brother, Michael, called to say that our father had tried to kill himself.

headline: Who Cares About One Missing Child in an Indian Slum? Another Child
abstract: Deepa Anappara’s novel “Djinn Patrol on the Purple Line” probes the secrets of a shantytown as a 9-year-old boy tries to solve the mystery of a classmate’s disappearance.
lead_paragraph: DJINN PATROL ON THE PURPLE LINEBy Deepa Anappara

headline: New in Paperback: William Trevor’s ‘Last Stories’ and Dani Shapiro’s ‘Inheritance.’
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: LAST STORIES, by William Trevor. (Penguin, 213 pp., $17.) These 10 tales from the Irish virtuoso of the short story, who died in 2016, center on ordinary people whose lives veer in surprising directions. “In this small, final, seemingly quiet but ultimately volcanic book of stories, Trevor denies and defies — maybe spites — the promise of decline,” Cynthia Ozick wrote here.

headline: Revisiting Stephen Wright and Historical Fiction
abstract: This week, Kevin Wilson reviews Stephen Wright’s new novel, “Processed Cheese.” In 2006, Laura Miller wrote for the Book Review about “The Amalgamation Polka,” Wright’s novel about the descendant of both ardent abolitionists and unwavering slaveholders.
lead_paragraph: This week, Kevin Wilson reviews Stephen Wright’s new novel, “Processed Cheese.” In 2006, Laura Miller wrote for the Book Review about “The Amalgamation Polka,” Wright’s novel about the descendant of both ardent abolitionists and unwavering slaveholders.

headline: The Stars of ‘Homeland’ Get Their Final Debriefing
abstract: After eight seasons and multiple Emmys, Claire Danes and Mandy Patinkin discuss their partnership and their struggle to accept that it’s really over.
lead_paragraph: On a chilly January afternoon, Claire Danes and Mandy Patinkin arrived safely at the Library at the NoMad Hotel, a book-lined coffee and cocktail space in Midtown Manhattan. No one had been kidnapped on the way. Or forcibly institutionalized. “But it’s still early,” Patinkin said.

headline: How Ulla Johnson, Fashion Designer, Spends Her Sundays
abstract: They start with a run around Prospect Park and end with a home-cooked dinner, board games and a cup of tea.
lead_paragraph: During the week, the fashion designer Ulla Johnson spends most of her time in her SoHo studio or traveling to countries like Kenya, Peru, or India for materials and inspiration. On weekends, however, she tends to stay within a tight radius of her Fort Greene brownstone. “My vision and the actual logistics of my life are so scattered, with the travel and work and the sourcing and everything, it’s nice to be close to home,” she said.

headline: Australian Open 2020: Matches to Watch on Friday Night (Into Saturday)
abstract: Sofia Kenin and Garbiñe Muguruza will meet in the women’s final in the early hours of the morning, followed by the mixed doubles final.
lead_paragraph: Sofia Kenin, the 14th seed, reached her first Grand Slam final by beating Ashleigh Barty, the world No. 1 and homegrown favorite at the Australian Open. Kenin and Barty both looked tentative in opening exchanges, but it was Kenin, the young American, who late in the first set began to take more initiative on points.

headline: Why the 49ers Play Hide-and-Seek Before Every Snap
abstract: The San Francisco 49ers reached the Super Bowl in part because of a counterintuitive strategy: Instead of giving the ball to their best players, they use them as human decoys.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The San Francisco 49ers relied on the N.F.L.’s best tight end, its highest-paid fullback and a cadre of productive receivers to reach the Super Bowl. But while other teams might strive to get those players into the end zone by any means possible, San Francisco has adopted the opposite strategy.

headline: Book Covers, Reimagined
abstract: An artist gives a fresh new look to favorite reads from her youth.

headline: ‘Sesame Street’ Is Opening Up to Syrian Refugees
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'Television', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Puppets']
abstract: What happens when the people who invented educational television try to reinvent humanitarian aid?
lead_paragraph: In its 50 years on television, “Sesame Street” has presented an expansive idea of the challenges of childhood, offering lessons on divorce, racism, grieving and autism — as well as help with the alphabet and accepting friends who are a bit taller and more birdlike.

headline: What We Lose by Hiring Someone to Pick Up Our Avocados for Us
keywords: ['Delivery Services', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting']
abstract: Will the proliferation of mobile ordering destroy civic life?
lead_paragraph: For the past few years I have made a habit of going to a particular Starbucks in Brooklyn after I drop my son off at school, a ritual that has given me pleasure way out of proportion to its ordinariness.

headline: Roommates Forever
abstract: For many New Yorkers, a roommate is a necessary evil, something to be tolerated until they can manage the rent on their own. Not everyone sees it that way.
lead_paragraph: Lauryn Hamel met James Monahan when both were students in the theater department at Hofstra University.

headline: Millennials Aren’t Spending All Their Money on Avocado Toast, Actually
keywords: ['Millennial Generation', 'Generation X', 'Savings', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', '401(k), 403(b) and 457 Plans', 'Student Loans', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: They are burdened by student loans, but new data shows they have saved more for retirement than Gen Xers did at the same age.
lead_paragraph: Millennials are often labeled the poorest, most financially burdened generation in modern times. Many of them graduated from college into one of the worst labor markets the United States has ever seen, with a staggering load of student debt to boot. Beginning a career underemployed can depress earnings over a lifetime and delay milestones like purchasing a home and having children. Not surprisingly, millennials have accumulated less wealth than Generation X did at a similar stage in life, primarily because fewer of them own homes.

headline: For Better or Worse, Trump Will Get His Favorite Things on Super Bowl Sunday
abstract: His pregame interview with Sean Hannity offers unfettered airtime in front of a huge national audience.
lead_paragraph: Of all the surreal things I’ve seen during Super Bowl telecasts in my lifetime — the wardrobe malfunction, Left Shark, whatever in the world they’re doing to poor Mr. Peanut — I’m not sure anything feels more discordant with the way we live today than the fact that Bill O’Reilly interviewed President Barack Obama before two Super Bowls.

headline: I Am 35 and Running Faster Than I Ever Thought Possible
abstract: My quest to qualify for the Olympic marathon team trials.
lead_paragraph: In early December, I ran a marathon faster than I had ever dreamed. I had never thought an athletic breakthrough like that would be possible, especially not in my 30s.

keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Revolutionary War, American (1775-83)']

headline: Bernie Sanders Can’t Win
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Class loathing feels so good, but it is ultimately self-defeating.
lead_paragraph: Watching “Succession,” the HBO show about the most despicable plutocrats to seize the public imagination since the Trumps were forced on us, made me want to tax the ultrarich into a homeless shelter. And it almost made a Bernie Bro of me.

headline: Taliban’s Continued Attacks Show Limits of U.S. Strategy in Afghanistan
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Civilian Casualties']
abstract: The number of attacks, detailed in a quarterly inspector general report, highlights once more the disparity between talking points and the reality on the ground.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Taliban and other groups carried out a record number of attacks in Afghanistan during the last several months of 2019, according to an inspector general report released Friday. The increase in violence occurred during a period in which President Trump tweeted that the United States was “hitting our Enemy harder than at any time in the last ten years!”

headline: No More Doggies in the Window? N.Y. May Ban Retail Pet Sales
keywords: ['Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Law and Legislation', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Pets', 'Breeding of Animals', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: After an investigation revealed abuses at a shop in Manhattan, support for a bill to ban retail sales of dogs, cats and rabbits.
lead_paragraph: The little puffs of puppies and kittens frolicking in the pet-store window on Seventh Avenue in Manhattan invariably drew an adoring crowd of passers-by outside the shop. But inside Chelsea Kennel Club, the reality was far less picturesque.

headline: A Traveler’s Guide to the Best Bets in Las Vegas
abstract: Take the bus, look for daytime performances, eat tacos and splurge on museums that immerse you in Vegas lore.
lead_paragraph: I have spent a lot of money in Las Vegas, and I don’t gamble much. I’ve paid $250 for a Cirque du Soleil ticket, taken a gondola down the faux canals of Venice for $60 and, on occasion, vastly exceeded my wine budget.

headline: Masks Are On. Games Are Canceled. Fear of the Coronavirus Comes to U.S. Colleges.
abstract: There has only been one confirmed case of the virus at a college campus, but anxiety is palpable in classes and dorms.
lead_paragraph: At the University of Wisconsin-Platteville, two undergraduates from Wuhan, China, were moved to a special dorm room and told to regularly take their temperatures. At Arizona State University, a student-led petition called for classes to be canceled after a confirmed case of coronavirus. Basketball games were postponed at Miami University in Ohio after two students who had recently returned from China displayed possible symptoms.

lead_paragraph: And now, all eyes turn to Iowa.

headline: 12 Deaths in Mississippi Tell a Grim Story
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Forced Labor']
abstract: The only way to “fix” a problem like the American prison system is to end it.
lead_paragraph: Twelve people have died in Mississippi state prisons since the start of the new year. Nine deaths occurred in the Mississippi State Penitentiary at Parchman. At least one was a suicide. Most were a result of violence between inmates: beatings, stabbings and other fatal altercations.

headline: China Targets the Coronavirus, and Farmers Pay a Price
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: The government’s efforts to stop the outbreak could push the country’s already struggling small businesses over the edge.
lead_paragraph: The fifth day of the Lunar New Year holiday, which fell on Wednesday, is when people in China welcome the god of fortune into their homes. This year, business owners like Qiu Xiangjian would be grateful if the god merely helped them get by.

headline: Iowa Will Be the First Test Case for 2020 Election Security
keywords: ['Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Voting and Voters', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Computer Security']

headline: How Private Equity Buried Payless
keywords: ['Private Equity', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Productivity', 'United States Economy', 'Hedge Funds', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions']
abstract: Finance-driven capitalism was supposed to make the economy more dynamic. A failed shoe chain shows why it hasn’t happened.

One was capitalizing on enthusiasm for the 2018 World Cup in the Latin American countries where the company had hundreds of stores.

lead_paragraph: AKRON, Ohio — Here you see a precious 100-year-old trophy. It is made of sterling silver, lovingly created for a team championship, and first presented at a prominent gathering inside an old-world hotel.

keywords: ['E-Cigarettes', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Nicotine', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'your-feed-healthcare']

headline: Bound by Their Boston Neighborhood
abstract: Linda Walczak had some advice for her husband, Bill, before she died: Meg Campbell was someone he should consider as a potential love interest. She was right.
lead_paragraph: When Bill Walczak called Meg Campbell to ask her for a date in 2016, he hung up happy. The yes he had received wasn’t particularly enthusiastic, but her hesitant acceptance gave him a lift anyway. Spending time with Ms. Campbell, he knew, would be good for him. His wife had told him so.

abstract: It may take months for federal investigators to determine what caused an aircraft carrying nine people to plummet into a Southern California hillside.

headline: What Does It Mean to Have a Serious Drinking Problem?
keywords: ['Alcohol Abuse', 'Women and Girls', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: Alcohol was my stress reducer, my reality fighter, the conferrer of artificial joys. It was also wreaking havoc on my life.

keywords: ['Soccer', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Political turmoil may have roiled Westminster. But on wet fields across Britain, a fourth-tier team shows what it looks like to just get on with it.
lead_paragraph: PORTSMOUTH, England — The team bus for the Leyton Orient women’s soccer team can sometimes be stifling. More than a dozen players sit, shoulder-to-shoulder, for hours in tedium under fluorescent blue lights (and in fear of having to use the one bathroom). There is, at least, free tea.

headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows New on Netflix Canada in February

headline: John Delaney Ends Presidential Campaign After Two and a Half Years
abstract: Mr. Delaney’s campaign was one of the longest in American history, spanning almost the entirety of the Trump presidency, but he dropped out three days before the Iowa caucuses.

headline: Anne Cox Chambers, Media Heiress and Ex-Ambassador, Dies at 100
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Media', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Mrs. Chambers, whose stake in Cox Enterprises was once worth billions, campaigned for Jimmy Carter, who gave her a diplomatic post in Belgium.
lead_paragraph: Anne Cox Chambers, the heiress to the Cox family media empire who went door-to-door campaigning for Democratic politicians, served as ambassador to Belgium during the Carter administration and helped bankroll museums and other causes, died on Friday at her home in Atlanta. She was 100.

headline: Britons on Brexit: ‘We’ve Made a Spectacle of Ourselves’
abstract: As Britain’s withdrawal from the European Union becomes a reality, some people are celebrating and others are mourning. But for most, it seems, it is a time for recuperation and healing.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When Britain leaves the European Union at 11 p.m. on Friday, some will be celebrating and others will be mourning. But for most people interviewed this week around the country, it seems to mark a time for recovery — from years of wrangling that has upended the political system and sometimes strained the country’s social fabric.

headline: Review: She Returns to Lead the Philharmonic. For Real, This Time.
abstract: The conductor Simone Young, a last-minute replacement in April, is back this week, on her own terms.
lead_paragraph: Last April, the conductor Simone Young, who had not returned to the New York Philharmonic since her debut in 1998, saved the day by jumping in on short notice to conduct the orchestra in Mahler’s Sixth Symphony.

headline: 7 Podcasts for a Healthier Mind and Body
keywords: ['Podcasts', 'Medicine and Health', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Exercise', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Whatever version of wellness you’re seeking, there’s a show to get you in better physical and emotional shape.
lead_paragraph: Now that we’re a month into the new year, it’s statistically likely that whatever health resolutions you set for 2020 have already lost their luster. Luckily for those in need of some straightforward training tips and expert motivation to help get back on track, plenty of coaches and nutritionists are available in audio form. Other shows explore health through individual stories of survival, endurance and transformation, or through candid interviews in which guests reflect on their psychological struggles. Whatever version of wellness you’re seeking, here are seven podcasts to get you in better physical and emotional shape.

headline: In the Met Opera’s ‘Agrippina,’ the Roman Empire Never Ended
abstract: A contemporary-dress Handel production calls to mind “House of Cards,” “Succession” and your choice of rulers in the age of Trump.

keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Sexual Harassment', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', '#MeToo Movement', 'Women and Girls', 'Movies']

lead_paragraph: Jessica Mann met the film producer Harvey Weinstein at a party after she had moved to Los Angeles from a dairy farm in Washington State to pursue acting. The Hollywood mogul seemed to take an immediate interest in her career.

headline: A Place of Their Own
abstract: As newlyweds, Queenie Dong, and her husband, Zee Zheng, helped Mr. Zheng’s parents run a restaurant in the Bronx. A year and a half ago, they opened Chuan Tian Xia in Sunset Park, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: As newlyweds, Queenie Dong, and her husband, Zee Zheng, helped Mr. Zheng’s parents run a restaurant in the Bronx. A year and a half ago, they opened Chuan Tian Xia in Sunset Park, Brooklyn.

headline: Sichuan That Moves Beyond Spiciness at Chuan Tian Xia
abstract: At this Sunset Park, Brooklyn, restaurant, mala — the province’s distinct marriage of numbing force and feral heat — is only one shade of the meal.
lead_paragraph: Yu xiang qie zi is fish-fragrant eggplant, which has no fish. It is simply, grandly, eggplant treated like fish, cooked with paojiao — chiles pickled but still bright — and doubanjiang, a paste of broad beans left to ferment for months, then dosed with chiles and fermented some more. Ginger brings sweetness, vinegar the sourness of time.

headline: Nike Vaporfly Shoes Avoid Olympics Ban
abstract: Track and field’s world governing body ruled that the next-generation running shoes could be worn in the Tokyo Games, but issued new rules that would outlaw certain modifications.
lead_paragraph: In a highly anticipated decision in the running world, the world governing body for track and field announced Friday that Nike’s Vaporfly shoe, the chosen footwear of the world’s fastest marathoners but one that has drawn scrutiny for its performance-enhancing effects, will be permitted during the Tokyo Olympics.

headline: 3 Major U.S. Airlines Suspend China Flights Over Coronavirus
abstract: American, Delta and United will halt service to the Chinese mainland, widening the impact of the outbreak on business and travel.

keywords: ['Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']

lead_paragraph: After three years of uncertainty, political acrimony and fractured opinions across a nation that found itself divided as never before, Brexit finally arrived on Friday night.

headline: The Queer, Half-Deaf Actor Redefining the Idea of a Leading Man
abstract: Gideon Glick shines — and sings — in a moving Off Broadway revival of “Little Shop of Horrors.”
lead_paragraph: “He’s a strange little man.” That’s how the New York actor Gideon Glick describes Seymour Krelborn, the menschy, dorky, ultimately murderous antihero of the cult classic musical “Little Shop of Horrors,” whom Glick, 31, is currently playing through March in an Off Broadway revival that runs at the Westside Theater. The production opened in October with the actor Jonathan Groff in the role, but Glick, who was at the time starring as Dill Harris in Aaron Sorkin’s Broadway adaptation of “To Kill a Mockingbird,” filled in for two weeks in November when Groff had a conflict. At the end of that temporary stint — during which Glick’s deep skills as one of New York’s best contemporary character actors (namely, his ability to channel his own inherent strangeness, his high voice often cracking, his knees seemingly quaking) were on full, glorious display — the director, Michael Mayer, asked if he wanted to take over the role after Groff finished his contract.

headline: A Convention for Broadway Fans? They’re Singing My Song
abstract: When I covered BroadwayCon last weekend, I saw rapturous fans, spontaneous singalongs, outrageous cosplay — and myself.

headline: Does It Matter Who the Democrats Choose?
keywords: ['Primaries and Caucuses', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In terms of actual policy, probably not very much.
lead_paragraph: At this point, the Democratic presidential nomination is very much up in the air. Not only is it unclear who will be the nominee; it’s unclear whether the nominee will be a centrist like Joe Biden or Amy Klobuchar, or a representative of the party’s left like Bernie Sanders or Elizabeth Warren. Whoever wins, there will be much wailing and gnashing of teeth from the other side.

headline: In Praise of American Cheese
abstract: Homemade Hamburger Helper, lemony shrimp and bean stew, sheet-pan roast chicken: Here are recipes for blustery days or peak-exhaustion nights.
lead_paragraph: Welcome back to Five Weeknight Dishes. For some recipes, American cheese is a gift from the gods. Take macaroni and cheese, for one; queso, for another. And it’s the key to from-scratch Hamburger Helper, which I stirred together at the last minute on a blustery evening this week. (I knew my kids would like it as soon as I read Priya Krishna’s tip that it was invented by the culinary director of Shake Shack.)

headline: Belgium Acquits Three Doctors in Landmark Euthanasia Case
keywords: ['Euthanasia and Assisted Suicide', 'Doctors', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: It was the first time doctors were prosecuted after having administered euthanasia, in the case of a 38-year-old woman who died in 2010.

headline: In Talks on Taxing Tech Companies, It’s America vs. the World
abstract: Leaders are divided over a global solution to taxing Silicon Valley giants, a fight for big tax dollars that threatens to disrupt global trade.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Trump administration and leaders of other wealthy nations remain at odds over how to tax technology companies and other businesses that operate online, negotiators confirmed on Friday, an impasse that threatens to inflame global trade tensions if not resolved by year’s end.

headline: 195 Quarantined in California After Fleeing Coronavirus Epicenter
abstract: The U.S. government took the rare step with American evacuees flown home from Wuhan, China, and said it would quarantine others returning from recent travel in the region.
lead_paragraph: The United States government has imposed a two-week federal quarantine on 195 people who were evacuated on Wednesday from Wuhan, China, to a California military base, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said on Friday.

keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Discrimination', 'Segregation and Desegregation', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Slavery (Historical)', 'Decisions and Verdicts']

headline: At Sundance, a Glorious Diversity of Voices Breaks Through
abstract: Onscreen at this year’s festival, you could find poetry, tragedy, comedy and, most important, the range of lived experiences around the world.
lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah — A runaway bride, wildly rambunctious women and two quietly resolute girls — the Sundance Film Festival is one movie celebration where the so-called second sex consistently comes out on top. Now in its 36th year, the festival has long made room for female filmmakers even when there weren’t all that many. In 1985, its inaugural year, it presented 85 movies, 10 from female directors, about half non-Americans like Lina Wertmüller, one of the few such filmmakers on anyone’s radar back then. Of this year’s 128 features, nearly half are from women. (The festival ends Sunday.)
